reviewText: A convict is caught between two not so great alternatives -  living with savages who were very good to him and returning to English prison. Don't want to say more and spoil it for viewers. Acting is so-so, but the beauty of Australia, views of aboriginal culture, and the story of survival made it a good watch.

Wonderful documentary on the life of William Buckley and how he was sent from England to Australia to the penal colony or basically dumped on a continent for apparently stealing some cloth he was holding in England? The documentary quickly goes through his life of 25 years of how he lived with the Aborigines is extraordinary.  Also life circumstances gave him no other choice but to live and be taught by aborigines who took him in as a spirit. Humanity chose him and he also chose humanity and love.  Because the aborigines believed he was a spirit he was not allowed to fight in any tribal wars and was very respected through the  many years.  I especially liked the part where he says that the girls and the woman were almost all the cause of all the problems!
This a fun adventure film done documentary style that also provides insight into the indigenous people of Australia.
An interesting story about a history I was not aware of.
Not what I was expecting

This is a story of a Man running for years in the Outback from English servitude and wilding into Aboriginal life. He is awash in fear as The Tribe accepts him and teaches Aboriginal beliefs and practices. 42 years later he must again choose between English and Aboriginal forces. Narrated but the narrator envelops well into the film seeming more like a character. I enjoyed the settings and filming, the acting was good, and the storyline stayed the test between action and dialouge!

4 THUMBS UP

Perhaps the aborigine still had a connection with the past, but the modern intellectual Englishman appeared cut off from the psyche of this history of William Buckley. It was good. I enjoyed it. I did not know about William Buckley before I saw this. I can't really say it was a family movie, and many of the themes are quite dark (cannibalism, tribe fighting, abuse of native populations) but hey, it's history, and history can be dark. If you are a survival buff, or if you like history films, this may be for you, but I would not suggest it for a date night or a movie to bring home to your wife for the evening. I guess it verifies the one inescapable truth of history: man's abuse against fellow man. I feel sorry for the people depicted in this film. I hope that future generations will find a way to be kinder and more respectful of each other, until then, films like this can at least document what happened in the past.

Aussie television historic recreation of a man who was lost after leaving a work camp and thought dead during the initial settling of Australia by Europeans. He spent nearly 3 decades living with aboriginal peoples, who by an interesting turn of chance, thought he was a ghost. They call in experts to interpret a lengthy nineteenth century interview that survives of his account. The beliefs and practices of the Aborigines before extended contact with Europeans was actually more interesting than Buckley's story to me.
They pushed the "Robinson Crusoe" analogy a bit hard, so it just missed the 4th star to me. It times in as an interesting hour of viewing if you are interested in this sort of thing. If you really like it, I suggest reading Comanche Summer, which tells stories of Americans kidnapped and adopted by Native Americans, mostly in Texas and New Mexico, at about the same time in history.

As an Aussie now in exile myself, it was incredibly nostalgic and true to life. This is the THE STORY we learned in childhood history. Buckley lived almost 32 years in the Australian wilderness with aborigines before turning up again in 1835.  It just amazes me that he lasted that long given the long periods of solitude in a harsh environment.  Even today, it would be hard to survive in the more remote parts of Australia without help.  His story gave rise to the Australian saying, "you've got Buckley's chance.." for something that seems impossible.  It's also a story that gives incredible insight into the first inhabitants of Australia whose lives were to tragically change for the worse soon after settlement of Port Phillip Bay. I am fortunate enough to have a copy of both the short three page manuscript that Buckley wrote soon after his arrival in Tasmania (Van Diemen's Land) in 1837 and also the one that was coaxed out of him by John Morgan, in 1852, who is the interviewer in the movie.  This drama has elements of both stories and is, I think, pretty accurate. I recommend this movie for the scenery and the insights it gives to aboriginal life.

For those interested in the anthropological studies of these people, this offers an excellent insight, although much is only briefly touched upon.  The man himself, William Buckley, was a resourceful and intelligent man, a survivor first and foremost.  The angst he felt as the inevitable collision of two world views unfolded before him was real, and his story is a sad one.  This is a balanced and fair treatment of both points of view, and well worth the viewing.  I appreciate that it glorifies neither side, but seeks to document what happened without judgment, but rather as a factual presentation.

A British prisoner escapes from one of the first camps that attempts to explore and perhaps start colonies in Australia. Prisoners were used as labor, and it was a good way for the UK to get rid of some of the "less desirable's". After escaping, and nearly succumbing to the wild flora and fauna of the outback,  William Buckley survives an encounter with Australia's indigenous peoples, he lives with the Aboriginals of Australia for over twenty years, becoming one of them. He has some hard decisions to make when the British come back. Should he protect his new people? Or should he rejoin his countrymen as they begin to exploit the many valuable resources that is so prevalent in this new country?

Well filmed, well acted movie. I loved it!
I have always enjoyed tales of human endurance and perseverance.  I was a little disappointed in how the story was portrayed in the movie.  Watching it was certainly not a waste of time though.
Interesting story that is well presented

Valuable window into the clash of cultures, when people with different values and assumptions meet for the first time. Makes very clear both white and aboriginal cultures were much more violent and accustomed to death than they are today. Shows the richness of aboriginal culture, beliefs, gentleness, innocence, and brutality all combined. Mr. Buckley lived with an aborigine tribe for much of his 30 years living in what is now Australia. The program also shows how western culture tried to bend and twist the story Mr. Buckley told in order to fit it into the standard narrative of the day, the civilized man meeting the savage.
Enjoyed the story.
Good movie..not too long which is also good.
Just ok
Documentry...very good...very sad what happened to the aborigines.
Informative and interesting....
It was good.  I never knew the story so this helped.  How accurate it is I couldn't say but it was interesting.

This is a very well put together little film. Its about half documentary and half docudrama. The acting and narration are balanced to tell an great story of a man caught between two cultures. The use of a Wathaurung spokesman and Wathaurung actors really gave the story credibility.
Informational, eye opener for those pioneering days in Australia.
Time well spent for all ages.  Some (appropriate) nudity.
Pretty good documentary.
Decent flick.  Well presented with sound historical context.
Kept our attention
I had no idea about this story.  It was very interesting and well made.  If you are documentary buff you should check it out!!
Great movie
Good movie not a great one
I liked watching this little film because of its educational aspects.  Acting was good.

An interesting docu-drama about the beginnings of Australia.
I enjoyed it.
Pretty Good.
Very well done
Dull.

I watched this on a whim, being a bit of a history buff and intrigued by the cover photo. I was very pleasantly surprised. Very interesting story beautifully told. I particularly appreciated the disclaimer at the beginning, warning that the biographer may have taken some liberties. I was also astonished at the quality of the acting in a short docudrama. WB's character is very well played. Highly recommend.

This reminded me of the chronicles of Cabesa de Baca; a Spanish Conquistadore shipwrecked in the Gulf of Mexico. He walked through the American Southwest, living with the stone-age Native Americans and learning to survive--their way. It's one of the great all time adventures and was made in to a so-so Spanish movie. I had never heard of William Buckley until I saw this movie and was struck by some of the parallels in their stories...
But unfortunately spottily told.  Certainly worth the watch if you know nothing about him and are interested in the time period.

Extraordinary Tale doesn't adequately describe this film!  Fantastic and beyond any real life docudrama, I have ever seen!  A true story of survival that surpasses Robinson Crusoe!  Seeing is believing and not viewing it would reduce your overall appreciation of life in general and take away the value you would gain by watching the resilience and pluck of an Englishman who overcame his past, but became a legend to the Brits and Aborigines amongst which he lived stranded for over thirty years.  Compelling in a way like "Jeremiah Johnson", Kit Carson, and Buffalo Bill!
Excellent story.  It is one I never had heard before.
I'm a professional anthropologist. The movie looked way too faked to me. Corny acting. not credible as a true ducumentary, to me. Thomas Headland
Educational and yet very very entertaining.  A must watch.
Truly a look into another place and time.

The story of William Buckley is a very interesting life, about survival and choosing between two cultures, the  aborigines or the English. I really enjoyed it, and I think you would too, especially if you have been to Australia, it is a must see!
What a great insight of aboriginal people! Buckley had a chance to see the real Australia before the whites ravaged it to oblivion. Presented well, and a minimum of embellishments, a good movie!
very interesting enjoyed the history

This was very interesting. Unfortunately - as they brought up in the documentary itself - the writer of his biography had his own slant on things so, I feel, a great deal of the details were lost. Worth watching.
I liked the actor, but the documentary itself did not share half of what it should have, and it just left me empty.  It could have been a winner.
A bit of history from Australia. A man with a stake in two world's, quite interesting and  definitely worth a look
Well cast and told story of a man who spent 32 yrs with the aborigines of Australia. I wish it had ben a longer documentary so as to tell us more.
Worth watching.
interesting story..sad what white men did to all natives everywhere.

This was an amazing and excellently made documentary. I was immediately drawn into the plight of Buckley and how he truly evolved throughout the course of his life. I could have easily watch another hour of this film. Super interesting with so many wonderful details of Aboriginal culture. Fantastic from start to finish! This should be much more highly regarded!
This is a simple straightforward true story about a man who breaches a new world and then finds it collapsing into his old world.  As others have said this deserves a re telling with full length.

I enjoyed this tale of William Buckley.  I wish there were more films like it.  It is an incredible true story of imprisonment, escape, survival and adaptation to the Aboriginal way of life.  Then almost 30 years later, used, betrayed and outcast by his own people after they had taken advantage of his knowledge.
like america, the whites take land that belongs to everyone. sad story. no one wins. i would recommend this movie.
Interesting historical movie.  Its a wonder how some people can survive and carry on.
